solution: An integer is divisible by $18$ if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by $9$ and the last digit is even (meaning it is divisible by both 9 and 2).  The sum of the digits of 142857 is 27, so this number is a multiple of 9.  The number is odd, so it is not a multiple of 18.  Instead the number is 9 more than a multiple of 18.  Therefore  $$\boxed{9}\equiv 142857\pmod {18}.$$
model_solution:
Step 1: Since $142857\equiv -1\pmod{18}$, we want to find the integer $n$ such that $n\equiv-1\pmod{18}$ and $0\le n<18$.
Step 2:  Since we want an integer $n$ such that $n\equiv -1\pmod{18}$ and $0\le n<18$, we can see that $n=\boxed{17}$ satisfies these conditions.

full_steps: Step 1: Since $142857\equiv -1\pmod{18}$, we want to find the integer $n$ such that $n\equiv-1\pmod{18}$ and $0\le n<18$.
Step 2:  Since we want an integer $n$ such that $n\equiv -1\pmod{18}$ and $0\le n<18$, we can see that $n=\boxed{17}$ satisfies these conditions.
